items.description: River Arrow and River Alne
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Little Alne river gauge as a result of Storm Bert.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible to begin this morning and afternoon 27/11/2024.  We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Arrow between Studley and Salford Priors and the River Alne between Bird in Hand and Alcester on the River Alne including farmland and caravan parks.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 6 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow 28/11/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by tomorrow morning 28/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:
Rain has fallen over the overnight on top of the rain experienced from Storm Bert.
River levels are increasing moderately at the Brokenborough gauge in response to last nights rain and will keep levels high during the rest of the week so flooding is still possible.
Areas most at risk include locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 28/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are rising steadily at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Consequently, the risks of flooding to low-lying land and roads remains. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   
No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high into the weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road and Sileby Mill road, and farmlands at Cossington, Sileby, Barrow, Quorndon and Cotes.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 6 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 18:00 on 27/11/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wreake in Leicestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
The risk of flooding from Storm Bert has now reduced.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 6 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:

This morning's rain should clear by the afternoon, leaving this evening and overnight mainly dry. Levels are expected to continue falling today at Witney and areas upstream. Levels around Newbridge will continue gradually rising as water moves downstream. We expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days.

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow, 28/11/24, or earlier as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Nene
items.message: River levels remain high following recent heavy rainfall in the River Nene catchment. The Lower River Nene is now rising, and will remain high over the next few days, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties is likely, and therefore flood warnings are expected to be issued from tomorrow. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine on Wednesday 27th November, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Kym in Bedford Borough and Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are rising steadily in response to rainfall overnight and this morning. Flooding is possible this morning and throughout the day today, Wednesday 27 November 2024. Areas most at risk are around the River Kym and River Til from Yelden, and Upper Dean to Hail Weston. If you have property level resilience, you are advised to install it now. Find out if your community assistance centre is open at www.bedford.gov.uk. There is no significant rainfall forecast over the next few days. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 6pm today, Wednesday 27 November 2024.

items.description: River Leam and River Itchen
items.message:

We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington.
Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon Wednesday 27/11/24. However, drier conditions are forecast this evening and tomorrow Thursday 28/11/24, 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning Thursday 28/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray for Islip
items.message:
Property flooding is expected. 

River levels are high but dropping slowly on the River Ray between Lower Arncott and Islip following heavy rainfall from Storm Bert and water moving downstream. Therefore, flooding of property and roads is expected to continue between Lower Arncott and Islip today, 27/11/2024. Areas most at risk are properties located closest to the river on Mill Street. 

This morning's rain should clear by the afternoon, leaving this evening and overnight mainly dry. River levels between Lower Arncott and Islip are expected to continue to drop slowly today. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall and may rise again later this week in response to the forecast rainfall.  

Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. Do not drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Combe Haven
items.message: The Powdermill Stream through Crowhurst is higher than normal, but stable, following 20mm of rain Wednesday morning. Rain has now cleared eastwards, and only isolated showers are forecast through to and including Saturday. River levels in Crowhurst should fall through Wednesday afternoon and evening. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, the Recreation Ground, rural roads and gardens in Crowhurst should now ease through the rest of Wednesday. It is possible that a small amount of flooding could affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe Wednesday evening and Thursday. However, impacts should remain minimal. The forecast is uncertain, but rain Sunday 01/12/2024 could see minor flood impacts return. Please remain prepared for the possibility of flood risk increasing on Sunday, and keep flood protection products installed, or close by, in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if property flooding becomes possible.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.     

 

No further significant rainfall is expected over the next 48 hours but showers are possible. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.  

 

We are closely monitoring the situation.      

 

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.    

 

This message will be updated by 10:00 on Thursday 28/11/24, or as the situation changes

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely today, Wednesday 27th November, and for at least the next 24 hours. The forecast high tide at Great Yarmouth will restrict the Broads river system from draining out to sea, which will result in higher than normal water levels within the Broads. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 28th November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is stable at 8.90 m. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.91 m and is rising very slowly. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Draycott, Law Lane, above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m.
Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover pumping stations when river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel will be opened once Parrett spillways stop running.
Tuesday will be mainly dry, however, there will be further rainfall from 7pm which will clear through the early hours of Wednesday.
The situation is being continually monitored and staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Refer to https://www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates for details of local road closures.
This message will be updated by 2 PM on 27/11/2024 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Blackwater
items.message: The water level in the River Blackwater at Ower and Cadnam River continues to fall following heavy rainfall over the weekend, when 56mm of rain was recorded in Romsey.  Later this evening (Tuesday 26/11/24) further heavy rain is forecast with up to 40mm expected. If this rain impacts the river, then flooding of land, roads and a small number of properties is expected. It is possible that a Flood Warning will be reissued tomorrow. The weather will be dry from Thursday (28/11/24) to Saturday (30/11/24) so any flood impacts which do occur, will be relatively short term in nature.  Our operations staff will work to ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure that pumps used to protect property are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on 27/11/24.

items.message:
River levels on the River Brue have now fallen, but the flood alert remains in force due to significant water on the Somerset Levels and Moors. There remains a risk of the flooding of roads and low lying land during Wednesday 27/11/2024. Flooding is possible near the River Brue and River Sheppey, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the B3151 Glastonbury to Meare Road. 
Drier weather is forecast for Wednesday and Thursday, but showers return on Friday and into the weekend. We continue to monitor the situation closely, and our staff are checking rivers for blockages, clearing weed screens, and checking flood defences. Please remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions, and avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk. This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 28/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Landford to Wade Bridge on the River Blackwater
items.message: The water level in the River Blackwater at Wellow and Ower is high and rising. Throughout the course of the night, very heavy rain (27mm) has been recorded in Romsey. This is a large amount in a short period of time. Over the next 12 - 24 hours, more significant out of bank flooding will affect land and roads at West Wellow, Landford and Ower. From 12:30 this afternoon, the river will be high enough to flood the Mill at East Wellow. Rain has now cleared the area. Water levels will be similar to those experienced over the weekend. The river will peak at around 17:00 this evening (27/11/2024). Our operations staff are ensuring the River Blackwater is kept free of blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please take appropriate action to protect property and ensure pumps used to lower water levels are operating. This Flood Warning will be updated by 12:00 on 28/11/2024.

Flooding of low lying land, roads and properties is expected to continue today, 27/11/2024, especially in the Abingdon area. This morning's rain should clear by the afternoon, leaving this evening and overnight mainly dry. River levels are expected to continue slowly falling today, but remain sensitive to further rainfall.

items.description: Cuckmere River
items.message: Between 15 and 30mm of rain is forecast through the early hours of Wednesday. There remains uncertainty, but if as much rain falls as predicted, flooding could be possible. From 04:00 27/11/2024 minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads, and gardens of properties on Mill Lane, Hellingly, and Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm. From 08:00 27/11/2024 flood impacts could also affect gardens of Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. From 12:00 27/11/2024 minor flooding could also affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Almost no rainfall is predicted Wednesday afternoon, through to the weekend. The rivers in Hellingly should begin to fall by 18:00 27/11/2024, returning to normal by Thursday morning. In Alfriston, river levels will not begin to fall until Thursday. Plan to avoid driving on routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road, Hellingly, and North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 16:00 27/11/2024.

items.description: River Uck
items.message: The River Uck is high and still rising in Isfield, following 20mm of rain Wednesday morning. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, and gardens near Hempstead Mill on Hempstead Lane, Uckfield, the Roller Mill, Uckfield, and near Isfield Mill and Isfield Bridge, Isfield. The river is already falling in Buxted, and should peak in Uckfield by 13:00 27/11/2024. Only isolated showers are forecast Wednesday afternoon, through to Saturday. The river should begin to fall in Isfield by 19:00 27/11/2024. The River Uck should return to normal through all communities by Thursday morning. The forecast is uncertain, but rain Sunday 01/12/2024 could see minor flood impacts return. Flood protection products are recommended to be kept installed in Buxted and Isfield, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 14:00 28/11/2024.

items.description: Western Rother
items.message: River levels are high and rising along most of the Western Rother, following Wednesday morning's rain. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, and gardens in Liss and Sheet. However, river levels are now slowly falling in Liss. From 15:00 27/11/2024 flooding will be close to isolated riverside properties in Iping, Stedham, and at North Mill and The Wharf, Midhurst. Property flooding is now likely at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. From 17:00 27/11/2024 flood water will approach properties at Lodsbridge, near Selham. From 02:00 28/11/2024 flood water will affect Fittleworth Mill, and nearby properties in Fittleworth. Almost no rainfall is predicted Wednesday afternoon, through to the weekend. In Iping, the river should begin to fall by 17:00 27/11/2024. At Lodsbridge, the river is unlikely to fall until 02:00 28/11/2024. River levels in Fittleworth might not fall until 16:00 28/11/2024. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 28/11/2024

items.message:

Observed peaks : 

Mythe 4.68m on Tuesday, 26/11/2024. 

Predicted peaks: 

Haw Bridge 5.0m to 5.2m Wednesday 27/11/2024,   

Sandhurst 3.3m to 3.5m Wednesday 27/11/2024,   

Gloucester 2.8m to 2.9m Wednesday 27/11/2024,   

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.   

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.   

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.

Almost no rainfall is predicted Wednesday afternoon, through to the weekend. The river should begin to fall by 01:00 on 28/11/2024, and should return to normal from 15:00 on 28/11/2024. items.description: Upper Ouse
items.message: The River Ouse is high and rising. 25mm of rain was recorded at Ardingly on Wednesday. This is a lot of rain in a short period of time. From 07:30 on 27/11/2024, flooding could affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach properties at Bridge Cottage and Dean's Water Mill at Lindfield Bridge on the B2028 near Lindfield. From 10:00 on 27/11/2024, flood water could affect gardens of properties on Sloop Lane, and roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. From 12:00 on 27/11/2024, flooding could also affect the Anchor Inn and gardens of properties at Barcombe Mills. Barcombe Mills road could become impassable. Very little rain is expected until Sunday 01/12/2024. The river should begin to fall by 12:00 on 27/11/2024 near Ardingly, but not until 22:00 on 27/11/2024 near Barcombe, where flood impacts could continue until Thursday afternoon. Please plan to avoid driving through routes that often flood, including Barcombe Mills Road. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 on 27/11/2024

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely through today, Wednesday 27th November. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas between Horsford and Crostwick on the Spixworth Beck, and Corpusty, Saxthorpe, Itteringham, Ingworth, Aylsham and Burgh-next-Aylsham on the Bure. It is likely that we may need to issue more warning messages for a wider area, over the next few hours. The forecast is for further rainfall this morning. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message tomorrow morning, Thursday 28th November, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is expected. 

A flood warning is in force for the River Thames and tributaries at New Botley, New and North Hinksey and Grandpoint in Oxford. River levels are rising gradually on the River Thames following heavy rainfall from Storm Bert. Therefore, flooding of property, low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 27/11/2024, especially in the Botley Road, Iffley, South Hinksey and Sandford areas. This morning's rain should clear by the afternoon, leaving this evening and overnight mainly dry. We expect river levels to continue rising over the next 24 hours as water moves downstream.

Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow, 28/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message:
Rising water levels in Currymoor are expected to cause flooding on Tuesday 26/11/2024. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Tone and on Currymoor, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. New Road has been closed.
The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is falling slowly and is 7.47 m. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 6.79 m and is stable. Pumping will start at Currymoor Station as soon as the river level allows. We are closely monitoring the situation.
Tuesday will be a mainly dry day, however, there will be further rainfall from 7pm which will clear through the early hours of Wednesday morning.
Plan driving routes to avoid New Road in Currymoor, which is affected by flooding. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Refer to https://www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates/ for details of road closures.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. Further rainfall is expected over the next few days with upto 20mm expected to fall over the next few days, which could see levels continue to rise.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 3/12/2024, or as the situation changes.

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. items.description: River Ray and Swinbourne for West Swindon area to above Water Eaton
River Dun
items.message: The water level in the River Dun at Dunbridge is high and rising. In the last 9 hours, 22mm of rain has been recorded at Broughton. This is a modest amount but follows a week of wet weather. From 09:00 this morning (27/11/24), the river will come out of bank and cause minor impact flooding to the road at Rectory Road, nearest the railway line at West Dean. Rain clears to the east by 08:00 this morning but the river may continue to rise until 12:00. As drier weather is forecast for the next few days, the water level should then recover. Our operations staff will ensure the river is free of any reported blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. At West Dean, we recommend moving any cars which are parked close to the river. This Flood Alert will be updated by 11:00 on 28/11/24.

items.description: Monks Brook
items.message: The water level in the Monks Brook is now falling as a result of dry weather over the last 6 hours. Minor flooding impacts affecting the recreational ground at Fleming Park will continue until around 18:00 this evening (27/11/2024). At Kingfisher Road, the river will be high throughout the rest of the day. Dry weather is forecast in Hampshire from today (27/11/2024) until Saturday (30/11/2024). River levels will return to normal over the next 24 hours and any minor flooding impacts will reduce. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. Given that the situation should improve, we will remove this Flood Alert by 12:00 on Thursday 28/11/2024.

items.description: Lymington River
items.message: The water level in the River Lymington is high and rising. In the last 9 hours, 33 mm of rain has been recorded at Brockenhurst. From 09:00 this morning (27/11/24), the river will be very high and drainage ditches through the forest will be flooding land and roads. It will be bank full as it flows through Martin’s Road and Balmer Lawn Road. Rain clears east at 08:00 this morning but another 5-10mm is expected in that time. The river is unlikely to peak until 15:00. It will be higher than recorded at the weekend and will flood gardens. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Watersplashes will deepen over the next 24 hours. Do not drive through floodwater. If you live near the river, please ensure you can protect property if required. This Flood Alert will be updated by 11:00 on 28/11/24.

items.description: Romsey Tadburn Lake
items.message: The water level in the Tadburn Lake at Botley Road is high and rising rapidly. Heavy and intense rain has fallen over the last 14 hours with 27 mm recorded at Romsey. This is close to half a month's rain falling in a short period of time and is fairly exceptional. From 10:30 this morning (27/11/2024), surface water flooding may affect property at the top of the river near Jenner Way and Sewards Rise. This could occur as very high levels in the river, prevents water on land from draining into it. Rainfall has now cleared the area. River levels should peak by 11:00 (27/11/2024) and will return to normal by tomorrow (28/11/2024). Our operational staff are checking the flood defence walls remain undamaged and are ensuring the river is free of blockages.   For those who have pumps to protect property, please ensure they are working correctly. This Flood Alert will be removed by 12:00 on 28/11/2024.

items.description: Bartley Water
items.message: At Ashurst Bridge and Woodland Road (near to Hazel Grove), the water level is high and rising. In the last 10 hours, half a month’s rain (32mm) has been recorded in Testwood. This is a large amount in a short period of time, especially when it follows a wet weekend. From 09:00 Wednesday morning (27/11/2024) out of bank flooding will affect land, roads and gardens at Woodlands and Ashurst. The depth of water in roads at Ashurst could be significant. Impacts are not expected at Totton, Rumbridge or Eling. Rain clears to the east at 09:00 and the rest of Wednesday should remain dry. The river should peak around 11:00 27/11/2024 and will remain high for at least an hour before it finally begins to fall. Our operational staff will ensure that reported blockages are cleared. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please avoid driving through floodwater, it will be very deep in some locations in Ashurst. This Flood Alert will be updated by 12:00 on 28/11/2024.

items.message:

Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue.   

We expect flooding to affect properties and roads around Mill Lane, Strensham.   

  

Observed peaks: Evesham 3.06m Monday, 25/11/2024. Bredon 3.15m Tuesday, 26/11/2024.      

   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.   

 

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.   

  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities.   Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.     

  
This message will be updated by 11am, Thursday 28/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
No further property flooding is expected. 

River levels are high on the upper River Cherwell following heavy rainfall from Storm Bert. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 27/11/24, especially in the Banbury area. This morning's rain should clear by the afternoon, leaving this evening and overnight mainly dry. River levels are expected to stabilise today in response to last night's rainfall, but should then continue to gradually fall over the coming days. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow, 28/11/24, or earlier as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent in Nottinghamshire
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Shardlow river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding to low-lying land and roads remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including communities near to the River Trent, and cellars of low-lying properties at Cavendish Bridge.   
No further significant rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high into the weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Burton Trent
items.message: River levels are steadily falling but remain high at the Croxall and Drakelow river gauges. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is still expected today, Wednesday 27/11/24 and possibly into Thursday, 28/11/2024. Flooding is likely to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Trent between Kings Bromley to Clay Mills including Burton upon Trent. No further significant rainfall is forecast today, although we are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out checking defences and clearing screens, and we are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated on Thursday 28/11/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon at Britford, Salisbury
items.message:
River levels are high and will remain steady at the Harnham Bridge River Level gauge following overnight rain. 
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Hampshire Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Lower Road and Church Lane.
We are closely monitoring the situation. No further rainfall is forecast until Friday 29/11/2024 and levels should start to slowly fall.
Please consider activating any property flood protection products and start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Move family, pets and cars to safety and turn off gas, electricity and water if it is safe to do so. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 28/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Curry Moor and Hay Moor
items.message:
Rising water levels in Currymoor are expected to cause flooding on Tuesday 26/11/2024. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Tone and on Currymoor, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. New Road has been closed.
The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is falling slowly and is 7.47 m. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 6.79 m and is stable. Pumping will start at Currymoor Station as soon as the river level allows. We are closely monitoring the situation.
Tuesday will be a mainly dry day, however, there will be further rainfall from 7pm which will clear through the early hours of Wednesday morning.
Plan driving routes to avoid New Road in Currymoor, which is affected by flooding. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Refer to https://www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates/ for details of road closures.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels in the River Welland remain high following recent heavy rainfall in the Lower Welland area, leading to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. items.description: River Avon at Twyning
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Bredon river gauge because of recent heavy rainfall.  

 

Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads around Twyning Green.   

 

Observed Peaks: 

Bredon 3.15m on Tuesday, 26/11/2024.     

  

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.   

 

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.  

 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities.  

 

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

 

This message will be updated by 6pm, Wednesday 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes
items.message: Between 15 and 30mm of rain is forecast through the early hours of Wednesday 27/11/2024. There remains uncertainty, but if as much rain falls as predicted, flooding could be possible. From 01:00 on 27/11/2024, minor flooding could affect Lake Lane and Barnham Road, Barnham. From 08:00 on 27/11/2024, flood water could also affect land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre, parts of the Tescos on Shripney Road, and fields near Shripney Lane and the A259. Almost no rainfall is predicted for Wednesday afternoon, through to the weekend. The Barnham Rife should begin to fall by 12:00 on 27/11/2024, and should return to normal by 17:00 on 27/11/2024. In Bersted, the Aldingbourne Rife might not begin to fall until 21:00 on 27/11/2024. River levels should end up a little higher than following Storm Bert. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barnham, if you have them. We are clearing grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post, and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 18:00 on 27/11/2024.

items.description: River Lox
items.message: Between 15 and 30mm of rain is forecast through the early hours of Wednesday 27/11/2024. There is uncertainty, but if as much rain falls as predicted, flooding could be possible. From 08:00 on 27/11/2024 flooding could affect fields, rural roads, and gardens along the length of the River Lox, approach properties near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood, and isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold. Flood water may also affect riverside properties on Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. Rain could be intense, minor surface water flooding could affect some riverside locations in Loxwood village. Almost no rainfall is predicted for Wednesday afternoon, through to the weekend. The river should begin to fall by 02:00 on 28/11/2024, and should return to normal by Friday. River levels could end up a little higher than following Storm Bert. Please continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 16:00 on 27/11/2024.

Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 27/11/2024, especially in the Egham to Penton Hook areas. The forecast is for further rainfall this morning (27/11/2024) which should clear by the afternoon. Tomorrow is forecast to be mainly dry. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days. Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Langney Haven
items.message: Between 15-30mm of rain is forecast through the early hours of Wednesday (27/11/24). There remains uncertainty, but if as much rain falls as predicted, minor flooding could be possible. From 08:00 on 27/11/2024, minor flooding could affect a few gardens of properties in Langney Green. Fields and parkland including Shinewater Park might also be affected. Almost no rainfall is predicted on Wednesday afternoon, through to the weekend. The river through Langney should begin to fall by 23:00 on 27/11/2024, however river levels are likely to remain higher than normal until next week. River levels could end up similar to their height at the start of October 2024. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed at Langney Green, if you have them. We are operating our structures at Fence Bridge and Crumbles Gate to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 19:00 on 27/11/2024

items.description: River Adur West Branch
items.message: The River Adur is high, but now slowly falling following 30mm of rain Wednesday morning. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads between Coolham and Henfield, isolated farm buildings, and possibly gardens of Church Close, Shipley. Almost no rainfall is predicted Wednesday afternoon, through to the weekend. The river should continue falling Wednesday afternoon and evening, returning nearer to normal by 10:00 28/11/2024. Some roads, including the Coolham road at Slaughter Bridge, may be affected by flooding, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 14:00 28/11/2024

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon and tributaries
items.message:
Rising river levels overnight may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible from 7:00 PM on 26/11/2024.
Areas most at risk include tributaries between Salisbury and Ringwood.
Further rainfall is forecast overnight which may lead to river levels remaining high..
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
Move family, pets and cars to safety and turn off gas, electricity and water if it is safe to do so.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames at Culham
items.message:
Property flooding is expected. 

River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of heavy rainfall from Storm Bert. Therefore, flooding of property and roads is expected today 27/11/2024. Areas most at risk are on Abingdon Road in Culham. 

This morning's rain is expected to clear by this afternoon, leaving this evening and overnight mainly dry. River levels are expected to continue rising steadily over the next few days and should stabilise on 28/11/2024. 

We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services. Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. 

This message will be updated this afternoon, 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels have started to rise this morning, 27 November after heavy rainfall overnight. Flooding is likely to continue until Wednesday evening. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads along Swalecliffe Brook in Swalecliffe and around Herne Bay. River levels are currently expected to peak later on Wednesday morning.
We are closely monitoring the situation and are checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions and be prepared for further warnings. This message will be updated by 6pm on Wednesday 27 November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame at Dorchester
items.message:
Property flooding is expected. 

River levels are increasing quickly on the River Thame following heavy rainfall earlier in the week from Storm Bert. Therefore, flooding of properties, low lying land, and roads is likely today, 27/11/2024. Areas most at risk are properties closest to the river where it passes through Dorchester. 

This morning's rain is expected to clear by this afternoon, leaving this evening and overnight mainly dry. River levels are still rising and may continue to rise again in response to water moving downstream. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid contact with flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this afternoon, 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Carisbrooke and Hunny Hill on the Lukely Brook
items.message: The water level in the Lukely Brook at Carisbrooke is high and rising. In the last 7 hours (most of which has fallen in the last hour), heavy and intense rain (30 mm) has been recorded at Carisbrooke. This is a large volume in a short period of time. From 04:15 this morning (27/11/24) property at the bottom of Castle Street could flood from rising river levels and surface water flowing down the road. The Aquatics Centre at Vicarage Walk near Foxes Road will also flood. Water levels will be very high at Caesars Road and Old Westminster Lane, and the river could come out of bank, flooding roads and parked cars. Further heavy rain is forecast over the next 4 hours. This will cause the river to rise until at least 10:00 this morning (27/11/24). Our operational contractors are out in the area now, making sure the river is kept free of blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection now. This Flood Warning will be updated by 15:00 on 27/11/24.

items.description: St Johns, Ryde
items.message: The water level in the Monktonmead Brook at St John's Station is high and rising. Heavy and intense rain has fallen, with 25 mm in 6 hours recorded at Ryde. This is a large amount in a short period of time. From 04:30 this morning (27/11/24), water will begin to flow across the railway tracks. Further heavy rain is expected to impact the area for at least the next 4 hours with an additional 10-15mm expected. The river will continue to rise until approximately 10:00. Before then, it is possible that we may issue a Flood Warning for impacts to the station depot buildings, and compounds located next to the railway line near Park Road. Our operational staff are keeping the Monktonmead Brook clear of blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please consider moving vehicles from depots located next to the river and railway line. This Flood Alert will be updated by 15:00 on 27/11/24.

items.description: Low lying areas close to the River Great Ouse at Bedford
items.message:
River levels are rising steadily in response to rainfall from Storm Bert earlier this week. Flooding is possible throughout today, Wednesday 27/11/2024. 
Areas most at risk are Marina Court, the brewery on Havelock Street, St Pauls Square, Duckmill Lane, Longholme Boating Lake, Priory Marina, the hotel and girls school on Cardington Road and Castle Mill. If you have property level resilience, you are advised to install it now. 
After this morning, there is no significant rainfall forecast over the next few days. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 6pm today, 27/11/24.

items.description: West Brook at Emsworth
items.message:
Water levels in the West Brook at Emsworth are now falling following heavy rain over night and this morning (27/11/24).
The weather is now fairly dry over the next three days. This will give the river a good chance to recover. More unsettled weather, bringing further bands of rainfall is forecast for Hampshire from Sunday (30/11/2024).  Should this rain affect the brook, then we may need to issue further advice.  Please remain prepared for ongoing minor impact flooding over the next few days.

items.description: River Medina
items.message: The water level in the River Medina at Blackwater and Shide is high and rising. In the last 5 hours, 30mm has been recorded in Cowes. This is a very large volume in a short period of time. From 04:45 this morning (27/11/24), out of bank flooding will affect land, gardens and possibly roads at Blackwater, especially at Blackwater Hollow on the A3020 near the Mill Farm, and at Sandy Lane. By 05:30 the river will become very high at St George's Way, Shide. Rain will continue to impact the area over the next 6 hours with a further 10-15mm forecast. At this time, property flooding is not expected, but much depends upon the intensity of the rain which is still expected to fall. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Road and land flooding impacts will be more significant at Blackwater. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. This Flood Alert will be updated by 14:00 on 27/11/24.

items.description: Areas near the River Nene from Thorpe Waterville to Eaglethorpe
items.message: We have seen heavy rain in the River Nene catchment and this has caused the River Nene to rise significantly, and is forecast to continue to rise, remaining high over the next few days. Low lying areas near the River are already flooded and properties in Eaglethorpe close to the river Nene are expected to be affected first. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Please avoid contact with flood water. Our staff are out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council. We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated online and on FloodLine on Thursday 28th November, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Eastern Yar
items.message: The water level in the Eastern Yar is high and rising. In the last 7 hours, 30mm of rain has fallen at Wroxall. This is a significant amount in a short period of time. Today (27/11/24), the river will impact cycle, and access tracks across the Yar Valley including at Horringford. From 16:00 this afternoon at Langbridge and Alverstone Road Bridge, the river will be close to the top of the riverbank, and flooding of Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road at Sandown is also expected. Rain should clear away by 08:00 but another 5-10mm may be recorded in this time. At Alverstone, the river will continue to rise until at least 19:00 this evening (27/11/24), and at Sandown until 07:00 on 28/11/24. We may issue a Flood Warning later today. We are managing levels at Bembridge sluice.  We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure any products used to protect gardens and property from flooding are operating. This message will be updated by 11:00 on 28/11/24.

items.description: Ching Brook in the London Borough of Waltham Forest
items.message:
River levels are rising rapidly due to heavy rainfall, Wednesday 27th November. 
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Ching Brook. Areas most at risk include Empress Avenue; Waterhall Avenue; Studley Avenue; Haldan Road; West Walthamstow Forest.
The risk of flooding is expected to reduce later today.
Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
We are monitoring rainfall and checking rivers for blockages.
This message will be updated by 6PM, Wednesday 27th November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chandlers Ford to Swaythling
items.message: The water level in the Monks Brook is now falling as a result of dry weather over the last 6 hours. From today (27/11/2024) until Saturday (30/11/2024), dry weather is forecast. No further property flooding is expected, however, a Flood Alert for the Monks Brook will remain in force as minor flooding impacts will continue to affect the recreational ground at Fleming Park today (27/11/2024). River levels will return to normal over the next 24 hours. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information.

items.description: River Hamble
items.message: The water level in the River Hamble at Durley and Botley is high and rising. In the last 9 hours, 30mm of rain has been recorded in Bishops Waltham. This is a large amount in a short period of time. From 07:00 this morning (27/11/24), Durley School may experience flood impacts, as the Ford Lake will be rising rapidly. The Hamble will be increasingly high at Durley and Botley. At Botley, surface water flooding from the main road is currently possible. No property flooding is expected at Bishops Waltham. High tide at Southampton is at 08:25 with a forecast tide level of 2.04 mAOD (4.78m Chart Datum).  This is a low spring tide. Rain clears to the east by 08:00 this morning but another 5mm may be recorded in this time. The river will remain very high until 12:00 today (27/11/24). It is possible that a Flood Warning may be issued. We will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. We recommend installing flood protection at Durley School. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on 27/11/24.

items.description: Waltham Chase, Durley Mill and Botley on the River Hamble
items.message: The water level in the River Hamble at Durley and Botley is high and rising. In the last 10 hours, 33mm has been recorded at Bishops Waltham. This is a significant amount in a short period of time. Durley School could experience flood impacts imminently. From 08:30 this morning (27/11/24), flooding may commence at Botley Mills Craft and Leisure Centre. Land, garden and outbuildings may be impacted at Durley Mill. High tide at Southampton is at 08:25 with a forecast tide level of 2.04 mAOD (4.78m Chart Datum). This is a low spring tide. Rain clears to the east by 08:00 this morning but another 5mm may be recorded in this time. The river will remain very high until 15:00 today (27/11/24). We will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. We continue to monitor the forecast. We recommend installing flood protection if you have it. This Flood Warning will be updated by 18:00 on 27/11/24.

The forecast is for dry conditions after today, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Our workforce are out checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 28th November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Gurnard Luck
items.message: The water level in the Gurnard Luck at Marsh Road is high and rising. In the last 10 hours, 25mm of rain has been recorded at Cowes. This is a large amount in a short period of time. High tide at Cowes is expected at 08:50 Wednesday morning (27/11/2024). From 11:00 27/11/2024 properties situated nearest to the river in Marsh Road will experience garden flooding. Property flooding is not expected. Most of the rain has now cleared the area and the rest of the day will be dry. The river will continue to rise until 13:00 27/11/2024, before it can drain with the lowering tide. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. At high tide, please keep away from the river at Gurnard Road Bridge. Water will be deep and fast flowing. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on 27/11/2024.

items.description: Whitwell, Wroxall, Langbridge, Alverstone on the Eastern Yar
items.message: The water level in the Eastern Yar at Alverstone is high and rising. In the last 13 hours, 34mm of rain has been recorded at Wroxall. This is a significant amount in a short time. Golf Links Road, the access track at Horringford, cycle tracks, and footpaths across the Upper Yar Valley will become impassable. From 16:00 this afternoon (27/11/24) in Alverstone, the main road will flood near the main road bridge. Water will begin to surround property in Alverstone and Langbridge, flooding a small number of properties. Garden flooding is expected at Whitwell High Street. Rain will shortly clear the area. At Alverstone, the river will rise until at least 21:00 this evening (27/11/24). Dry weather is expected until Sunday 01/12/24. This will give the river a chance to return to normal levels. We will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. Please install flood protection now and leave it in place until Friday 29/11/24. This Warning will be updated by 21:00 on Thursday 27/11/24.

items.description: Rushington and Eling on the Bartley Water
items.message: At Ashurst and Woodlands, the river is high and rising rapidly. Heavy and persistent rain has fallen over the last 12 hours with 30 mm recorded at Lyndhurst. This is a significant amount in a short period of time. From 10:30 this morning (27/11/2024), flooding is expected to impact Ashurst Bridge and property at Woodlands Road. Impacts are not expected in the lower Bartley Water at Eling, Totton and Rumbridge. Rain has now cleared the area. The river will fall by 17:00 this afternoon (27/11/2024). Our operations staff will ensure the Bartley Water is kept free of reported blockages. We will continue to monitor the river. Please take appropriate action to protect your property. This Flood Warning will be updated by 12:00 on Thursday 28/11/2024.

items.description: Upper Arun
items.message: The River Arun is high and rising.  30mm of rain has been recorded at Itchingfield on Wednesday morning. Flooding is likely to be affecting grassy areas and gardens of Tanbridge Park and Blackbridge Court and fields behind Arunside and playground of Arunside School. From 12:00 27/11/2024 flood water will affect fields and gardens of isolated mill properties between Broadbridge Heath and Pallingham Quay. The A272 Newbridge road near Billingshurst could be affected. From 20:00 27/11/2024 properties at Pallingham Lock could be affected. Only isolated showers are forecast over the next 4 days. The river should begin to fall by 13:00 27/11/2024 in Horsham, and should return to normal from 23:00 27/11/2024. Nearer Pallingham the river will keep rising until Thursday afternoon 28/11/2024.  Flood impacts should begin to slowly ease when river levels start to fall. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Wanford, if you have them. Our sluice at Provender Mill is operating to reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 11:00 28/11/2024.

items.description: Lower River Medway
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels are rising in the lower river Medway, this morning Wednesday 27/11/2024, as a result of heavy rain overnight. Flooding of towpaths and low-lying land is expected from midday today. River levels are expected to remain high throughout the day until Thursday morning. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and towpaths close to the River Medway, at Yalding, Wateringbury and East Farleigh but particularly at Lockmeadow and the underpasses at Maidstone Town Centre. We do not expect flooding of property at this stage. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Further light rain is possible this morning but no significant rainfall is forecast for the next 48 hours. This message will be updated by 8pm this evening 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Arun
items.message: The River Arun is high. Nearly a month's rain (80mm) has been recorded over the past week. River levels are expected to rise again through Wednesday and Thursday. From 08:00 28/11/2024 flooding could affect the A29 at Pulborough. Water will be extensive through fields and could affect gardens and approach properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. Over each high tide, water will be close to the tops of the banks near Houghton Bridge, Amberley and may approach riverside properties, including near St Edmunds Cottage, Houghton. We do not currently expect flood impacts in Arundel, but the river will be high. Only isolated showers are forecast through to Saturday. The river in Pulborough could continue rising until Friday morning, and might not return to normal until next week. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Pulborough, Amberley and Arundel, if you have them. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 16:00 28/11/2024.

items.description: River Thames for Shiplake, Lower Shiplake and Wargrave
items.message: Property flooding is expected. River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of property and roads is expected later this afternoon, 27/11/24, especially in the Basmore Lane, Bolney Road, and Loddon Drive areas. No further rainfall is forecast, but we expect river levels to continue rising over the next 24 hours. We are monitoring the situation. Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Avoid contact with flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 27/11/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury on the River Adur
items.message: The River Adur is high and rising.  30mm of rain has been recorded at Haywards Heath on Wednesday morning. . From 14:00 27/11/2024 flooding will affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding will also affect properties near Mock Bridge and their gardens. Only isolated showers are forecast over the next 4 days. The river should begin to fall by 20:00 27/11/2024, and should return to normal from 10:00 28/11/2024.   Flood impacts should begin to slowly ease when river levels start to fall. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including the A281 at Mock Bridge. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 28/11/2024.

items.description: River Thames at Clifton Hampden, Dorchester and Little Wittenham
items.message:
Property flooding is expected. 

River levels are increasing quickly on the River Thames following heavy rainfall earlier in the week from Storm Bert. Therefore, flooding of properties, low lying land, and roads is likely today, 27/11/2024. Areas most at risk are properties in Clifton Hampden, Dorchester and Little Wittenham. 

This morning's rain is expected to clear by this afternoon, leaving this evening and overnight mainly dry. River levels are still rising and may continue to rise again in response to water moving downstream. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid contact with flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this afternoon, 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Eden and Eden Brook from Crowhurst to Penshurst
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: High river levels from heavy rain overnight are expected to cause flooding this afternoon. Flooding is expected from 13:00 on 27/11/2024. Areas most at risk include properties around Haxted Mill and Haxted Road. Weather conditions are expected to improve this afternoon with light showers on Thursday. We are closely monitoring the situation and checking rivers for blockages. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. This message will be updated by 8:00 PM on 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames at Thames Ditton Island

floodArea.county: Greater London, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are forecast to rise on the Thames as a result of high tides in combination with high flows from upstream due to heavy rainfall at the weekend. The next high tide is expected at Thames Ditton Island at 12:45 this afternoon (27/11/24) and is forecast to reach between 5.54 and 5.84m, therefore flooding of low lying land and roads is possible. The high tide after this is expected at 01:15 tomorrow morning (28/11/24) and is forecast to reach between 5.61m and 5.91m, therefore flooding of low lying land and roads is expected. The following high tide is expected at 13:30 tomorrow afternoon (28/11/24) and is forecast to reach between 5.52m and 5.82m, therefore flooding of low lying land and roads is possible from this tide.
The forecast is for a predominantly dry afternoon and day tomorrow. We are monitoring the situation. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Beult from Pluckley and Bethersden to Stilebridge
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels are rising as a result of heavy overnight, Wednesday 27/11/2024. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Beult and its tributaries around Smarden and Staplehurst. The rain is expected to clear this afternoon and no further significant rainfall is forecast for the rest of today or tomorrow. We expect river levels to remain high until Thursday 28/11/2024. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 8pm Wednesday 27/11/2024, or as the situation changes.
